issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:
The test fails after the following error messages:

{code}
java.io.IOException: Failed to replace a bad datanode on the existing pipeline due to no more good datanodes being available to try. (Nodes: current=[DatanodeInfoWithStorage[127.0.0.1:57377,DS-b4ec61fc-657c-4e2a-9dc3-8d93b7769a2b,DISK], DatanodeInfoWithStorage[127.0.0.1:47448,DS-18bca8d7-048d-4d7f-9594-d2df16096a3d,DISK]], original=[DatanodeInfoWithStorage[127.0.0.1:57377,DS-b4ec61fc-657c-4e2a-9dc3-8d93b7769a2b,DISK], DatanodeInfoWithStorage[127.0.0.1:47448,DS-18bca8d7-048d-4d7f-9594-d2df16096a3d,DISK]]). The current failed datanode replacement policy is DEFAULT, and a client may configure this via 'dfs.client.block.write.replace-datanode-on-failure.policy' in its configuration.
	at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSOutputStream$DataStreamer.findNewDatanode(DFSOutputStream.java:1280)
	at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSOutputStream$DataStreamer.addDatanode2ExistingPipeline(DFSOutputStream.java:1354)
	at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSOutputStream$DataStreamer.setupPipelineForAppendOrRecovery(DFSOutputStream.java:1512)
	at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSOutputStream$DataStreamer.processDatanodeError(DFSOutputStream.java:1236)
	at org.apache.hadoop.hdfs.DFSOutputStream$DataStreamer.run(DFSOutputStream.java:721)
{code}

In such case, the DataNode that has removed can not be used in the pipeline recovery.
fields.summary: TestDataNodeHotSwapVolumes.testRemoveVolumeBeingWritten fail due to no DataNode available for pipeline recovery.

comments.body: Update the test to add a new datanode after the volume being removed from a DataNode, so that it helps the pipeline to be recovered.

This message was automatically generated.

Hi [~eddyxu],

Thanks for working on this issue. 

I did a quick review, one thought, instead of adding a DN later, can we start a cluster of 4 DNs (which is more natural to me) instead for this test? Or maybe I missed something.

Thanks.

[~yzhangal] The DataNode is added later after hot swap is due to that we'd like to make sure the write pipeline is one the DataNode at the time that we remove the volume. If we set 4 nodes at the beginning, it will be 25% chance that it is not the case.
Ping [~yzhangal] would you give another review? Thanks!

Hi [~eddyxu] thanks for reporting the issue and submitting the patch. 

I am not seeing a DataNode get removed explicitly in the test. Only 1 volume (out of 2)  is removed on a DataNode, and that should not cause the DN to fail. I am curious to see if there are other issues in this test or code. Would you mind to shed some lights on it?

Thanks

Hi, [~jojochuang]

It is not because the DN fails, it is due to that the client / pipeline put this DN into excludeNode list. So it then adds a DN to help for pipeline recover.

Discussed with [~eddyxu], the concurrent write may be interrupted after the volume is removed, so client will then exclude that DataNode, therefore 3 DataNodes are not sufficient.

Based on the discussion I am +1. Thanks.
